subject: Important notice: We’ll turn on a Conditional Access policy for your organization during the week of June 10, 2024
body:
You don't often get email from mssecurity-noreply@microsoft.com. 
Learn why this is important
Review what actions to take before the policy is turned on.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
 
A Microsoft-managed Conditional Access policy in your tenant will be turned on the week of June 10, 2024
You’re receiving this email because you’re a Global Administrator, Security Administrator, or Conditional Access Administrator for LCW.
As part of our 
Secure Future initiative
, we created a 
Microsoft-managed Conditional Access policy
 in your LCW tenant. 
This policy, 
Multifactor authentication for per-user multifactor authentication users,
 was created in 
report-only mode
,
 which means that it doesn’t block any access, but it does generate reports on how it’ll affect users when it’s switched to the 
On
 state. Now that this policy has been in this mode for 90 days, it’ll be automatically turned to 
On
 during the week of June 10, 2024. 
Once the policy is on, all users covered by it will need to have multifactor authentication. 
The
 per-user multifactor authentication users 
policy doesn’t affect users’ experience as they’re already using multifactor authentication
. 
This policy helps you migrate to Microsoft Entra Conditional Access, which offers a number of 
improvements
, including a better admin experience and more granular access control. 
Required action 
To avoid any potential disruption to users’ access and to ensure that this policy meets your organization's needs, 
take the following actions before June 10, 2024: 
Review the 
effects and benefits
 of this policy. If you don’t want us to turn it on automatically, set it to 
Off
. Or, you may set it to 
On
 at any time.
Customize this policy according to your specific needs, such as 
excluding emergency access accounts
. To make more extensive customizations, you can duplicate Microsoft-managed policies and make any changes you need.  
Verify that all users covered by this policy have enabled and registered at least one multifactor authentication method. If necessary, 
run a registration campaign
 to set up the Authenticator app. 
Help and support 
Learn more about 
Microsoft-managed Conditional Access policies
. If you have questions or need help, create a 
support request
:
For 
Issue type
, select 
Technical.
For 
Subscription
, select your subscription. 
For 
Service type
, select 
Microsoft Entra Sign-In and Multi Factor Authentication
.
For 
Summary
, type a description of your issue.
For 
Problem type
, select 
Conditional Access
.
For 
Problem subtype
, select 
Microsoft Managed
. 
Account information
Tenant name:
LCW
Tenant ID:
3ca40a42-d72d-43c9-b92e-0740101d9dd3
Tenant name:
LCW
Tenant ID:
3ca40a42-d72d-43c9-b92e-0740101d9dd3
Did you find this email helpful?
 
Yes
 
No
 
Privacy Statement
 
Microsoft Corporation, One Microsoft Way, 
Redmond, WA 98052

subject: SCORM Cloud: Tipping Point
body:
Hey there RANDALL, 
It looks like you've been using your SCORM Cloud account a lot this month! You've just hit what we like to call the 'tipping point' on your plan. Basically, this is when you'll actually save money by upgrading to the next account level. 
We love to see folks actively using Cloud and we want to be sure you're on the plan that makes the most sense for you. And don't worry- you can change your account size at any time. It's 
almost
 too good to be true, but its not! 
Upgrading your account is easy- just click 
here
 and change your account type to The Big. 
Thanks, 
-- 
The SCORM Cloud Team 
Follow 
@SCORMCloud
 on Twitter! 
P.S. Did you know SCORM Cloud now supports the xAPI? 
Check it out!

subject: COBRA Complete Monthly Remittance Has Been Posted 163513888
body:
Hello,
 
The monthly remittance has now been posted in the COBRA Employer Portal.
 
To retrieve the Remittance Report, follow these steps:
 
Log into the COBRA Employer Portal.
Hover over the 
Reports
 tab and choose the 
Accounting Reports
.
Select 
Remittance
.
Click on the 
Report
 next to the most recent remittance.
Click on 
Queue Report
.
 
Please note that you are responsible for reconciling the remittance report against your carrier invoice and p
romptly reporting any discrepancies to us.  As a general matter, most insurance carriers are only able to address discrepancies such as missing enrollees or terminated enrollees within 60 days from the date of a carrier invoice.  We are unable to support communications with carriers regarding discrepancies that are reported to us more than 60 days from the date of the carrier invoice.
 
Thank you,
 
COBRA Complete Service Center
COBRACompleteEmployer@healthaccountservices.com
Cobra-complete.com
877-791-3399

subject: SCORM Cloud: Account Limit Reached
body:
Hey there RANDALL, 
Wow, you really have been busy! We just noticed you've created 100 registrations this month in your SCORM Cloud account, reaching your total included registration limit. 
Because your account is equipped to handle overages, any more registrations created during this billing cycle will only cost you an additional $3.60 per registration. Your next bill is scheduled for May 26. At that time, any overages will be calculated and charged and your usage will be reset. 
It may be time to think about upgrading your account (or maybe not, you know better than we do). If you do decide to upgrade, keep in mind that we have plenty of account tiers to choose from so you can find a usage level that best meets your needs. 
Log in
 to SCORM Cloud anytime to check out more information about your usage and to upgrade your account. 
Thanks! 
-- 
The SCORM Cloud Team 
P.S.- Did you know SCORM Cloud now supports the xAPI? 
Check it out!

subject: The Spring 2024 University of Chicago Magazine
body:
You don't often get email from laurademanski@uchicago.edu. 
Learn why this is important
Preview the new issue of the Magazine.  
Problems viewing this email? 
View online.
 
 
 
 
Dear Reader,
 
When I was a junior in college, the late Claire Rosenfield, my professor and BA adviser, let me into her Henry James graduate seminar. The course had a certain unforgiving math to it: five students plus one fat book a week equaled zero places to hide if you hadn’t done the reading.
 
But what forgave it all, and made you keep up, was our teacher’s way of opening one of those tomes like a Fabergé egg to expose the intricate workings inside. Thirty-five years have not dimmed the sense I had then of gaining new powers.
 
As the academic year winds down, my mind turns to teachers past and to those who have taught at the University of Chicago memorably well.
 
This month, teaching awards will be handed to two such scholars nominated by their past students when John J. MacAloon, AM’74, PhD’80, and Martha C. Nussbaum receive the Norman Maclean Faculty Award. Shortly thereafter, the University will name the newest recipients of the Llewellyn John and Harriet Manchester Quantrell Awards for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching and the Faculty Awards for Excellence in Graduate Teaching and Mentoring. The evidence suggests that for these teachers, there are few honors that mean more.
 
I spoke to MacAloon for this issue about his teaching and, with the Paris Summer Games approaching, his life’s research on the Olympics. At the end of the Q&A he encapsulates what educating students means to him and how he did that important work day to day, student by student. (To find out what and how, read “Light Bearer”
 
in this issue
.) For his and Nussbaum’s nominators, nobody did it better.
 
What did your best teacher do like nobody else? Tell us at 
uchicago-magazine@uchicago.edu
. We are always grateful to hear your stories and to share them with our community.
 
Finally, some staff news. As of April, Susie Allen, AB’09, is back at the 
Magazine
 as senior associate editor extraordinaire. You may remember Susie’s byline gracing our pages often from 2015 to 2023, as well as the issues that she artfully guest edited. Starting with the Summer/24 issue, the light of Susie’s writing will again shine down on all.
 
Best wishes,
 
 
 
Laura Demanski, AM’94
Editor
 
P.S. Be sure to check out this issue’s Alumni News (available only in print and 
on Box
) to find out what your classmates have been up to.
 
 
 
Read the Spring/24 issue:
 
•
 
Meet the College’s new dean, Melina Hale, PhD’98, who brings leadership experience and unlimited intellectual curiosity to her crucial role. 
•
 
Explore color in the ancient world with a researcher and a conservator from the Institute for the Study of Ancient Cultures.
•
 
Learn about John J. MacAloon’s (AM’74, PhD’80) life’s work studying the Olympic Games and his teaching philosophy.
•
 
Discover how the Divinity School is broadening its scope to include more world religions.
•
 
… Plus more UChicago stories.
 
 
Read the Spring/24 issue’s
 
Alumni News
.
Read
 
back issues
 
of the 
Magazine
.
Contact
 
the 
Magazine
.
 
 
 
 
 
 
The University of Chicago
5801 South Ellis Avenue
Chicago, IL 60637
1.800.955.0065
 
 
This University of Chicago Magazine Digital Edition email was sent to randall@lcwmail.com.
If you no longer wish to receive these emails, you may 
update your communication preferences
 at any time.
